title: 107_hr3223
content:
The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct water systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation, including service connections to facilities in Dulce and surrounding areas. Additionally, the Act requires the Secretary to enter into a self-determination contract with the Jicarilla Apache Nation upon request. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation, assuming ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Act", "BIA", "Irrigation", "Reclamation", "Report", and "Reservation" related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico includes lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. A Rural Water Supply Project serves towns, communities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads with clean water. The State refers to New Mexico, and the Secretary of the Interior oversees the project for the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation has a Rural Water System project overseen by the Secretary of the Interior for the Tribe. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services, pumping and treatment facilities, distribution and collection systems, and appurtenant buildings and access roads. The Rural Water Supply Project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services, pumping and treatment facilities, distribution and collection systems, and appurtenant buildings and access roads. The tribal share of the project costs includes designing and initiating construction of specific water treatment and distribution facilities. The Rural Water Supply Project includes water settling ponds, treatment plant, storage plants, transmission pipeline, and distribution pipelines. The Federal share of the project costs will cover all remaining costs identified in the Report. Upon completion, the Tribe will be responsible for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs in accordance with the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary has the authority to enter contracts and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe will develop an OM&R plan for operations. A construction manager will be selected to work with the Tribe. A memorandum of agreement will be made for operations and maintenance during construction. The Secretary will oversee the construction of the Rural Water Supply Project with the Tribe and provide technical assistance for planning and operation. The project's service area will be within the Reservation boundaries and will adhere to the Indian Self-Determination Act. Annual reports will be submitted during construction in consultation with Reclamation. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will report annually to Congress on the planning, design, and construction of the Rural Water Supply Project. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States and cannot be transferred without Congressional approval. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$45,000,000 (January 2002 dollars) authorized for the Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction. Funds can only be used after completion of appraisal, feasibility study, and NEPA requirements.

SEC. 8. PROHIBITION ON USE OF FUNDS FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS.

The Jicarilla Apache Tribe's water rights are included in the Water Rights Settlement Act and adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights or endangered species.
